title: Hall-Welter Speedrite 914 cheque writer and cover Hall-Welter Speedrite 914 cheque writer
content:
accession_no_csv: 2016-00401

  Image: 

  object_work_type: machines (general equipment)

  title_text: Hall-Welter Speedrite 914 cheque writer and cover Hall-Welter Speedrite 914 cheque writer

  preference: main alternative

  title_language: 

  creator_2: Hall-Welter Co Inc

  creator_role: manufacturers

  creation_date: 1970s - 1980s

  creation_place_original_location: United States Singapore

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: irregular

  materials_name: plastic (organic material) metal

  techniques_name: forming (physical activity) metalworking

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: The image depicts a gray cover with a device underneath. The lever on the right side of the device is protruding out from the covers. A cheque writer with red and white tops lies underneath. All the tops are aligned in a straight row near the top of the cheque writer. In the middle of the device
 there is a list of numbers
 and the ones from three to nine are visible. The name of the cheque writer
 Speedrite
 is displaye din capital letters at its front. There are no visible chips or cracks on the device. At the top of the device
 several small screens displaying the number two in a straight row can be seen. They are coloured either in red or black. Each number is aligned to a top that is located under the former.

  subject_terms_1: stamping (marking) technology (general associated concept) brand name objects checks (bank checks)

  subject_terms_2: Checks Embossing (Printing) Technology Brand name products

  sgcool_label_text: This Speedrite cheque writer (also termed ‘cheque protector’) by Hall-Welter Co Inc
 one of the established American manufacturers of cheque writers
 was manufactured in USA around the 1970s
 and was used to produce inked figures on a cheque by pulling the lever on the side of the machine. Machines like this would have been used by banks
 merchants and other financial institutions as they provided precise
 clear and quality output
 and prevented any fraudulent action such as alteration of the amount on the cheque.

metadata.title_text: Hall-Welter Speedrite 914 cheque writer and cover Hall-Welter Speedrite 914 cheque writer
metadata.physical_appearance: The image depicts a gray cover with a device underneath. The lever on the right side of the device is protruding out from the covers. A cheque writer with red and white tops lies underneath. All the tops are aligned in a straight row near the top of the cheque writer. In the middle of the device, there is a list of numbers, and the ones from three to nine are visible. The name of the cheque writer, Speedrite, is displaye din capital letters at its front. There are no visible chips or cracks on the device. At the top of the device, several small screens displaying the number two in a straight row can be seen. They are coloured either in red or black. Each number is aligned to a top that is located under the former.
metadata.subject_terms_1: stamping (marking) technology (general associated concept) brand name objects checks (bank checks)
metadata.subject_terms_2: Checks Embossing (Printing) Technology Brand name products
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This Speedrite cheque writer (also termed ‘cheque protector’) by Hall-Welter Co Inc, one of the established American manufacturers of cheque writers, was manufactured in USA around the 1970s, and was used to produce inked figures on a cheque by pulling the lever on the side of the machine. Machines like this would have been used by banks, merchants and other financial institutions as they provided precise, clear and quality output, and prevented any fraudulent action such as alteration of the amount on the cheque.
